availability.p: Zooming image © The Master and Fellows of Christ's College, Cambridge.

availability.licence: Images made available for download are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 3.0 Unported License (CC BY-NC 3.0)

summary.seg: This manuscript, probably copied in the late 16th century, contains a Miscellany of Greek ascetic texts, including Lives of Saints, other narratives about early ascetics and brief texts and excerpts giving spiritual guidance. Most are anonymous or of patristic origin, while others are by Byzantine or post-Byzantine authors.

The manuscript was copied by several different scribes, whose work was greatly interspersed, the more prolific scribes' hands appearing at several points through the manuscript. One copyist often took over from another in the middle of a page of text. Their styles vary greatly, some being compact and informal, while others wrote in a flamboyant, calligraphic hand derived from the late Byzantine Hodegon style, sometimes with ornate flourished tails often decorated with red ornament. Given the nature of the content, the manuscript can be supposed to have been produced for monastic use.

The manuscript was bought by the classicist and teacher W. H. D. Rouse on the island of Kalymnos in 1898. Another manuscript bought by Rouse on the same island that year, now MS Rouse 255, containing two hagiographic texts, was copied by two hands, both of which appear in this manuscript. This raises the possibility that they came from the same source and had a history of common ownership extending back to the time of production. Unfortunately, Rouse's note in the other manuscript recording this acquisition is vague about the purchase, saying only that the manuscript came from one of the numerous islands of the Sporades, while the equivalent note in this manuscript (f. [i] verso) gives no information on its provenance beyond the date and place of purchase.

msItem.title: Life of St Eulogios
msItem.rubric: f. 1r Δίηγησις ἐν τῷ γεροντικῷ πάνυ ὠφέλιμος
msItem.incipit: f. 1r Διηγήσατο ἡμῖν ὁ γέρων, ὡς περὶ ἄλλου τινὸς
msItem.explicit: f. 3v μᾶλλον δὲ ἀνθρωπαρεσκίᾳ στέργοντες

msItem.title: On remembering God
msItem.incipit: f. 3v Εἶπε τὶς τῶν ἁγίων· ὅτι ὀφείλει ὁ μοναχὸς, καὶ πᾶς χριστιανὸς
msItem.explicit: f. 4v ἀδύνατον γὰρ τὸν ἀκούοντα

msItem.title: On life after death
msItem.incipit: f. 5r βοηθῆσαι δύναται· ὅτι καὶ ἄρχων καὶ ἀρχόμενος
msItem.explicit: f. 11r μόνον σὺν τῷ ἀνάρχῳ Πατρί σου, εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας μετὰ τοῦ Πνεύματος, ἀμήν

msItem.title: On the love of God
msItem.rubric: f. 11r Περὶ τῆς εἰς Θεὸν ἀγάπης, Μαξίμου κεφάλαιον αʹ
msItem.incipit: f. 11r-11v Ἀγάπη Θεοῦ ἐστὶν, ἀγαθὴ κατάστασης ψυχῆς
msItem.explicit: f. 22v ὅσον ἀναβλύσει, τοσοῦτον τὸν διψῶντα καταφλόξει

msItem.title: On eating and drinking
msItem.incipit: f. 23r χεται πρὸς τὸν Θεόν· οἱ δὲ τὸν ἄρτον ἐσθίοντες
msItem.explicit: f. 23v ἐὰν δὲ ἡττηθῇς καὶ πλεῖον φάγης τοῦτο ἥττημμά σοι ἐστί

msItem.author: Isaias Gazaeus
msItem.title: Asceticon
msItem.rubric: f. 23v Τοῦ ἀββᾶ Ἡσαΐου
msItem.incipit: f. 23v Ἀδελφέ· καθήμενος ἐν τῇ τραπέζῃ μετὰ ἀδελφῶν
msItem.explicit: f. 25v ἔμελες θλίβεσθαι, καὶ ἀναπαύῃ

msItem.author: Diadochos of Photike
msItem.title: Capita centum de perfectione spirituali
msItem.rubric: f. 25v Τοῦ ἁγίου Διαδόχου
msItem.incipit: f. 25v Τὸ ἀπὸ πάντων τῶν παρατιθεμένων
msItem.explicit: f. 25v ἐν πάσῃ αἰσθήσει καὶ πληροφορία γευσόμεθα

msItem.title: Excerpt
msItem.note: Attributed here to John Cassian (c. 360-c. 435) Cassian, John, approximately 360-approximately 435
msItem.rubric: f. 25v Τοῦ ἀββᾶ Κασσιανοῦ
msItem.incipit: f. 25v Τὸ ἀνάγνωσιν ἐπιελεῖσθαι ἐν τοῖς κατὰ τὴν ἀνατολὴν
msItem.explicit: f. 26v ὅπως μηδεὶς ἔξωθεν τῆς τραπέζης τροφῆς μεταλάβοι

msItem.title: Apophthegmata patrum
msItem.rubric: f. 26v Ἐν τῷ γεροντιῷ
msItem.incipit: f. 26v Ἔλεγον οἱ πατέρες· ὅτι ἐσθιόντων ποτὲ τῶν ἀδελφῶν ἐν ἀγάπη
msItem.explicit: f. 28v ὡς θέλειν ἀπὸ μιᾶς πάντα φαγεῖν

msItem.author: Ephraem Graecus
msItem.title: Ad imitationem proverbiorum
msItem.rubric: f. 28vΤοῦ ἁγίου Ἐφραίμ
msItem.incipit: f. 28v Κρεῖσσον ἐστὶν ἐσθίειν καὶ εὐχαριστεῖν τῷ Κυρίῷ
msItem.explicit: f. 31v καὶ ταῖς χερσὶ τῶν ἐχθρῶν παρέδωκας σεαυτόν

msItem.title: Allegorical narrative
msItem.note: Defective at the beginning and end
msItem.incipit: f. 31r καὶ ἐλθὼν ὁ ὄφις, ἔδακε τὸν ἵππον αὐτοῦ
msItem.explicit: f. 44v παρ'αὐτοῦ αἰτεῖσθαι συγχώρησιν· ὅτι αὐτῷ πρέπει δόξα εις τοὺς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων, ἀμήν

msItem.title: On kindness to animals
msItem.incipit: f. 44v Λόγος ἐκ τῆς βίβλου Ἀντιόχου τοῦ παντέκτου· ὅπως δεῖ ἡμᾶς εἶναι εὐσπλάγχνους καὶ ἐν τοῖς ζώοις
f. 44v Ἐγένετό τις ἀββᾶς ὀνόματι Βαδιανὸς πάνυ ἐνάρατος καὶ φοβούμενος τὸν Θεόν
msItem.explicit: f. 45r ἡμεῖς οὐ γινώσκομεν πόθεν τυρννούμεθα

msItem.title: Ascetic narrative
msItem.incipit: f. 45v Εἰς τὸν Ἔδεσαν ἦτον τίς ἀδελφὸς
msItem.explicit: f. 45v οἱ ἀτελεῖς περὶ τῶν τελείων

msItem.title: Dialogue between Basil of Caesarea and Gregory of Nazianzus
msItem.rubric: f. 135v Διάλογος τῶν ἁγίων Βασιλείου καὶ Γρηγορίου τοῦ θεολόγου
msItem.incipit: f. 135v Βασίλειος· τί ἐστιν ἀρχή
msItem.explicit: f. 47v καὶ τὸ πᾶν σκότος. ὅτι ὅπερ εστίν ὁ Σατάνας

msItem.title: Ascetic narrative on Philemon
msItem.incipit: f. 47v Ἀδελφὸς τίς ἠρώτησε τὸν μέγαν ἐν ἀσκηταῖς Φιλήμονα λέγων
msItem.explicit: f. 48v ἢ διὰ τὸ μέγεθος τῆς περιεχούσης αὐτοὺς δόξης;

msItem.title: Life of St Alexios
msItem.incipit: f. 49r καὶ ἐνθυμηθήτης ὁ Θεὸς· διὰ τὰ Καλάτης ἔργα
msItem.explicit: f. 68r ὅτι αὐτῷ πρέπει δὀξα· κράτος· τιμὴ, καὶ προσκύνησις· εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων, ἀμήν

msItem.author: Dionysios Stoudites
msItem.title: Narrationes animae utiles VI
msItem.rubric: f. 68r Ἰστορία Διονυσίου ἱερομονάχου τοῦ ῥήτορος ἀσκοῦντος ἐν τῇ σκήτῃ τῆς Λαύρας
msItem.incipit: f. 68r Ἐγὼ ἀδελφοὶ ἀναγινώσκων τὰ βιβλία εὖρον θαύματα
msItem.explicit: f. 107v τὴν ἀδυναμίαν καὶ τὴν ἀναξιότητάτου ἔτζη ἐταπεινώση

msItem.author: Ephraem Graecus
msItem.title: Sermo in patres defunctos
msItem.rubric: f. 72r Τοῦ ἁγίου Ἐφραὶμ, λόγος εἰς πατέρας τελειθέντας ἐν τοῖς χρόνοις αὐτοῦ: ὁ λόγος οὗτος, ἀναγινώσκεται τῷ Σαββάτῳ τῆς τυρῆς
msItem.incipit: f. 72r Τὴν καρδίαν μου ἀλγῶ· συμπαθήσατέ μοι ἀδελφοὶ
msItem.explicit: f. 78r ποιῆσαι συντελείαν αἰῶνος τοῦ ματαίου· αὐτῷ ἡ δόξα εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων ἀμήν

msItem.author: John Klimakos (c. 579-649)
msItem.title: Prologus sive Protheoria ad Scalam Paradisi
msItem.note: Excerpt, defective at the end: PG 44, col. 629
msItem.rubric: f. 78v Δανιὴλ μοναχοῦ Ῥαϊθοῦ εἰς τὸν βίον τοῦ ἀββᾶ Ἰωάννου τοῦ ἐπίκλην Σχολαστικοῦ: + πεπείρακας κυροῦ (?) ἐν βραχέσι, πλεῖστα: ῥήτορσι γὰρ κάλλος, συντομία ἔπους
msItem.incipit: f. 78v Ἐσκόπησεν ὄντως ἀρίστως μάλα, ὁ τὴν ἱσάριθμον ἡμῖν
msItem.explicit: f. 78v ἐν πάση μαρτυρία καρδίας οὐκ ἀπόδεκτος εὑρεθήται

msItem.title: Ascetic narrative
msItem.incipit: f. 79r Ἕνας ἀδελφὸς ὀνόματι Πτολομαῖος ἐπέρασε μίαν ζωὴν τῆς ἀρετῆς
msItem.explicit: f. 79v ἐκαταχωρέθη δαιμόνιον πνεῦμα πονηρὸν καὶ τὸν ἐπείραζεν ὅλον ἕνα

msItem.author: Dionysios Stoudites
msItem.title: Metaphrasis of the homilies of Isaac to novice monks
msItem.rubric: f. 80r Λόγος τοῦ ἀββᾶ Ἰσᾶακ πρὸς μοναχοὺς ἀρχαρίους· μεταφρασθεὶς παρα Διονυσίου ἱερομονάχου τοῦ Στουδίτου, εἰς ὀφελείαν τῶν εὐρισκομένων
msItem.incipit: f. 80r Ἀδελφοὶ καὶ πατέρες· αὐτὰ τὰ λόγια καὶ ταῖς παραγγελίαις
msItem.explicit: f. 89v χάριτι τοῦ Χριστοῦ ἡμῶν Θεοῦ· ὧ ἡ δόξα καὶ τὸ κράτος· εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων ἀμήν
msItem.note: This text is also found in Venice, Biblioteca Nazionale Marciana, MS gr. 1167

msItem.author: Basil of Caesarea
msItem.title: Ascetica
msItem.rubric: f. 89v Ἐκ τῶν τοῦ μεγάλου πατρὸς ἡμῶν Βασιλείου Καισαρείας ἀσκητικῶν, περὶ πῶς ὀφείλει διάγειν ἐν κοινωβίω, καὶ ὅπως λέγονται κοινοβιάται: θαυμαστὸν
msItem.incipit: f. 89v Οἱ τὸ μοναχικὸν καὶ ἅγιον σχῆμα φοροῦντες, οὐ μόνον μὴ ἔχειν ἴδιον τί ἐν τῷ κοινωνίῳ, ὀφείλουσιν
msItem.explicit: f. 91v μᾶλλον δὲ προδοσία πίστεως, καὶ περὶ τὸ θεῖον ἀσέβεια
msItem.note: This text is also found in Paris, Bibliothèque Nationale de France, MS Suppl. gr. 1319

msItem.title: Biographical note on Marcellus
msItem.incipit: f. 91v Ὁ ἐν ἁγίοις πατὴρ ἡμῶν Μάρκελλος μετὰ ἄλλα αὐτοῦ κολλὰ
msItem.explicit: f. 91v ἐπέρασε τὴν ζωὴν αὐτοῦ μὲ κόπον καὶ ἔργα τῆς ἀρετῆς

msItem.author: Ephraem Graecus
msItem.title: Oratio in vanam vitam, et de paenitentia
msItem.rubric: f. 92r Τοῦ ἐν ἁγίοις πατρὸς ἡμῶν Ἰωάννου ἀρχιεπισκόπου Κωνσταντινουπόλεως τοῦ Χρυσοστόμου
msItem.incipit: f. 92r Ὅσοι τὰ τοῦ βίου ματαιὰ καὶ ἀπολλύμενα
msItem.explicit: f. 101r καὶ ἡ σωτηρία πάντων τῶν καταφευγόντων εἰς σὲ, εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων, ἀμήν

msItem.title: De Theodosio II imperatore
msItem.rubric: f. 101r Διήγησις περί τινος γέροντος σημειοφόρου μοναχοῦ· πῶς ἀπεκαλύφθη αὐτῷ, τὰ περὶ τοῦ βασιλέως Θεοδοσίου
msItem.incipit: f. 101r Γέρων τίς ἐκαθέζετο ἐν τῇ ἐρήμῳ· διατρέψας ἐν αὐτῇ, ἔτη τεσσαρακόντα
msItem.explicit: f. 106r δόξαν ἀναπέμπων Χριστῷ τῷ Θεῷ ἡμῶν, ἀμήν

msItem.title: Life of Xenophon, Maria, Ioannes and Arkadios
msItem.rubric: f. 108r Βίος καὶ πολιτεία τοῦ ὁσίου πατρὸς ἡμῶν Ξενοφῶντος τοῦ συγκλητικοῦ· καὶ τῆς γυναικὸς αὐτοῦ Μαρίας καὶ τῶν τέκνων αὐτῶν, Ἰωάννου καὶ Ἀρκαδίου
msItem.incipit: f. 108r Διηγήσατο τίς ἅγιος γέρων καὶ μέγας καὶ ἔλεγεν· ὅτι ἦτον τίς ἄνθρωπος εἰς τὴν Κωνσταντινούπολιν
msItem.explicit: f. 135r ἡτοιμασμένα ἡμῖν ἀγαθὰ ὑπὸ τοῦ Κυρίου ἡμῶν Ἰησοῦ Χριστοῦ· αὐτῷ ἡ δόξα εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων, ἀμήν

msItem.title: On sins
msItem.incipit: f. 135r Τῶν ἁμαρτημάτων τέσσαρας εἶναι βαθμοὺς οἱ ἅγίοι πατέρες φασὶ
msItem.explicit: f. 135r τῆς λειτουργείας ἐδισχεθήσεται· τουτέστι πρὸς καιρὸν ὀλίγον

msItem.author: Michael Glykas
msItem.title: Quaestiones in sacram scripturam (Cap. 41-98)
msItem.rubric: f. 136r Κεφάλαια ληπτικὰ εἰς τὴν ἁγίαν μετάληψιν, Μιχαὴλ φιλοσόφου τοῦ Γλυκᾶ
msItem.incipit: f. 136r Ἔτι καὶ τοῦτο ἠπόρηται, εἴτε φθαρτή ἐστιν
msItem.explicit: f. 137r ζήσωμεν ἐν Χριστῷ Ἰσοῦ τῷ Κυρίῳ ἡμῶν· ᾧ ἡ δόξα εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων, ἀμήν

msItem.author: Symeon of Thessalonike (d. 1429)
msItem.title: On the liturgy
msItem.rubric: f. 137r Συμεὼν ἀρχιεπίσποκος Θεσσαλονίκης, περὶ τῆς θείας λειτουργίας
msItem.incipit: f. 137r Ἡ θεία τάξις τῆς ἱερᾶς μυσταγωγίας, ἰδία παρὰ πάσας
msItem.explicit: f. 138r καὶ τὰ πρόσωπα ὑμῶν οὐ μὴ καταισχυνθῇ

msItem.author: John Chrysostom (d. 408)
msItem.title: De proditione Judae (homiliae 1-2)
msItem.note: Excerpt, defective at the end: PG 49, coll. 380
msItem.rubric: f. 138v Τοῦ Χρυσοστόμου ἐκ τοῦ λόγου τῆς μεγάλου εʹ
msItem.incipit: f. 138v Καιρὸς λοιπὸν τῇ φρικτῆ ταύτῃ προσελθεῖν τραπέζη· πάντες τοίνυν ἀπέλθωμεν
msItem.explicit: f. 139v ὅτι ὁ ἀδελφός σου ἔχει τίκτον σοῦ, ἄφες

msItem.title: Ascetic narrative
msItem.incipit: f. 140r Ἕνας ἀδελφὸς ἐπείραζαν οἱ λογισμοὶ οἱ πονηροὶ
msItem.explicit: f. 142r ὁ Θεὸς τοῦτο ἐν ἰδίῳ καιρῷ ἐχαρίζετο

msItem.title: On the Samaritan woman
msItem.rubric: f. 142r Ἰωάννου τοῦ Χρυσοστόμου
msItem.incipit: f. 142r Μιμησώμεθα τὴν Σαμαρεῖτιν γυναῖκα καὶ ἡμεῖς
msItem.explicit: f. 142r τὸν θάνατον τοῦ ἁμαρτώλου ὡς τὸ ἐπιστρέψαι καὶ τῆν αὐτόν

msItem.title: In Psalmum 50 homilia 1
msItem.note: The same passage is excerpted in Vienna, Österreichische Nationalbibliothek, MS Suppl. gr. 113, ff. 133v-134v
msItem.rubric: f. 142r Ἐκ τῆς ἑρμηνείας τῆς εἰς τὸν νʹ ψαλμὸν
msItem.incipit: f. 142r Τότε λοιπὸν ἀπῆλθε πρὸς τὸν Δαβὶδ
msItem.explicit: f. 143r καὶ τὴν οἰκουμένην ἐγχαρισθῆναι ἅπασαν

msItem.author: Isidore of Pelousion
msItem.title: Epistulae
msItem.rubric: f. 143r Τοῦ μοναχοῦ Ἰσιδώρου
msItem.incipit: f. 143r Τίνος ἕνεκεν ὁ Κάϊν καὶ ὁ Λάμηχ φόνον δράσαντες
msItem.explicit: f. 143r ἑαυτοῖς τὴν δίκην παρασκευάσωμεν

msItem.author: John Chrysostom, Saint -407
msItem.title: De beato Philogonio
Contra Anomoeos, homilia 6
msItem.rubric: f. 143v Τοῦ Χρυσοστόμου ἐκ τοῦ λόγου τοῦ εἰς τὸν μακάριον φιλογόνιον, πρὸ πεντε ἡμῶν τῆς Χριστοῦ γενήσεως
msItem.incipit: f. 143v Εορτὴ μέλλει προσελαύνειν ἡ πασῶν ἑορτῶν σεμνοτάτη
msItem.explicit: f. 144v ὅλον κερδήση, καὶ τὴν ψυχὴν αὐτοῦ ζημιωσθῇ

msItem.title: Excerpt
msItem.rubric: f. 144v Τοῦ αὐτοῦ
msItem.incipit: f. 144v Πολλοὶ τῆς θείας ταύτης ἅπαξ τοῦ ἐνιαυτοῦ μετέχουσι μεταλήψεως
msItem.explicit: f. 144v οὐχ ἁπλῶς φησιν ἁμαρτημάτων καθαρὸς, ἀλλὰ ἅγιος

msItem.author: Neilos of Ankyra (d. c. 430)
msItem.title: Epistulae
msItem.rubric: f. 144v Τοῦ ἅγιον Νείλου ἐπιστολὴ· ἣν ἀπέσται χαρικλεῖ πρεσβυτέρῳ ἀποτόμως ἐξερχομένῳ τοῖς πταίουσι καὶ χείλον τι μὴ ἀρκεῖν τὴν μετάνοιαν εἰς ἐξομολογησιν
msItem.incipit: f. 144v Πάνυ μοι δοκεῖς τὴν θείαν ἠγνοηκέναι γραφήν
msItem.explicit: f. 147v σῶσον τὸν δοῦλον σου δέσποτα τὸν ἐλπίζοντα ἐπὶ σέ

msItem.author: Anastasios of Sinai (640-700)
msItem.title: Quaestiones et responsiones
msItem.rubric: f. 147v Τοῦ ὁσίου πατρὸς ἡμῶν Ἀναστασίου τοῦ Σινὰ ὄρους, λόγος εἰς τὸν τῆς βλασφημίας δαίμονα
msItem.incipit: f. 147v Πόθεν ἡ ψυχὴ τοῦ ἀνθρώπου λαλεῖ τινὰς ἔνδοθεν λογισμοὺς
msItem.explicit: f. 149v τῷ τοιούτῳ περιπίπτει λογισμῷ

msItem.title: Ascetic narrative
msItem.incipit: f. 150r θέρμη τοῦ πόθου καὶ τῆς ἐπιγνώσεως αὐτοῦ
msItem.explicit: f. 150v μόνον ἐὰν εὔχης ὁμοψυχόν σου καὶ ὅμ[..] ἕνα ἢ δύο

msItem.title: Ascetic narrative
msItem.incipit: f. 150v Ἔλεγέ μας ὁ ἀββᾶς Ὢρ ὅτι ἠξεύρω ἐγὼ ἄνθρωπον ὁποῦ ἦτον εἰς τὴν ἔρημον
msItem.explicit: f. 150v ἐκεῖ ἔλεγον ὕστερον ὅτι ἐκεῖνος τὰ εἶδεν

msItem.title: Ascetic narrative
msItem.incipit: f. 151r τήσας μου τῆς χειρὸς, ἐποίησέ με καθίσαι
msItem.explicit: f. 158v ἐπλήσθη τὸ κελλίον καπνοῦ, ὡς ἀπὸ θεαφίου

msItem.title: Apophthegmata patrum
msItem.incipit: f. 159r λαλοῦντα τοὺς λόγους τοῦ κόσμου, ἔχειν παῤῥησία ἡ καρδία αὐτοῦ
msItem.explicit: f. 159r σκεπάζει μικρὰ νεφέλη ὑποδραμοῦσα· ταῦτα δὲ ἐπίστανται οἱ γνῶσιν ἄγοντες

msItem.title: Ascetic narrative
msItem.rubric: f. 159r Τοῦ εὐαγγελίου λόγος
msItem.incipit: f. 159r Ἠρωτήθη γέρων· τί έστι τὸ ὑπὲρ ἀργοῦ λόγος
msItem.explicit: f. 173v καὶ τί ἐστι χεῖρον τοῦ καθίσματος τῆς ἐρήμου, ἐὰν μὴ ταῦτ ἐάσωμεν

msItem.author: Ephraem Graecus
msItem.title: Sermo compunctorius
msItem.rubric: f. 173v Τοῦ μακαρίου Ἐφραὶμ τοῦ Σύρου λόγος περὶ ὠφελείας ψυχῆς, εὐλόγηον
msItem.incipit: f. 173v Δεῦτε ἀγαπητοὶ· τὸ ἐκλεκτὸν ποίμνιον τοῦ Πατρὸς· οἱ ἐσφραγισμέναι τοῦ Χριστοῦ στρατιῶται
msItem.explicit: f. 199r ὅτι αὐτῷ ἡ δόξα καὶ τὸ κράτος, σὺν τῷ Πατρὶ καὶ τῷ Ἁγίῳ Πνεύματι· εἰς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων, ἀμήν
msItem.note: Ed. Giuseppe Assemani, Sancti patris nostri Ephraem Syri Opera omnia quae exstant Graece, Syriace, Latine, 6 vols. (Rome 1732-1746), vol. I, pp. 28-40

msItem.author: Amphilochios of Ikonion (d. 394)
msItem.title: Life of St Basil
msItem.rubric: f. 199v Τοῦ ἐν ἁγίοις πατρὸς ἡμῶν Βασίλειος ἀρχιεπίσκοπος Καισαρείας Καππαδοκίας τοῦ μεγάλου περὶ τῆς γυναικὸς τῆς ἁμαρτωλοῦ τῆς διὰ προσευχῆς αὐτοῦ ἀφεθείσης τὰς ἁμαρτίας αὐτῆς
msItem.incipit: f. 199v Ἐν τοῖς χρόνοις τοῦ ἁγιωτάτου καὶ μακαριωτάτου ἀρχιεπισκόπου Βασιλείου· τοῦ τῆς Χριστοῦ βασιλείας κληρονόμου
msItem.explicit: f. 206r ἀλλὰ καὶ ἁμαρτίας τῶν ἐν πίστει προσερχομένων αὐτῷ ἀφιέναι

msItem.author: Amphilochios of Ikonion (d. 394)
msItem.title: Life of St Basil
msItem.rubric: f. 206r Περὶ Ἰωσὴφ τοῦ ἰατροῦ καὶ Ἑβραίου
msItem.incipit: f. 206r Ἰωσὴφ τίς τ'οὔνομα, ἦν ἐν τῇ πόλει ἰατρὸς
msItem.explicit: f. 209v πάντως εὑρίσκειν ἀυτὸν τελειωθέντα· θεασάμενος δὲ αὐτὸν ἔτι ζῶντα, καὶ

msItem.title: Ascetic narrative
msItem.note: Defective at the beginning and end
msItem.incipit: f. 210r εξετον Πέτρον· καὶ ἐποίησεν ὅτι νὰ ἀρνηθῇ τὸν Χριστόν
msItem.explicit: f. 136r καὶ προσκύνουμεν· καὶ δοξάζομεν· νῦν καὶ ᾀεὶ καὶ εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων, ἀμήν

support.note: The whole manuscript is composed of Western paper, but due to the extent of damage to the edges of folios and their repair with thick paper, including in the gutter, it has not been possible to identify watermarks in many parts of the manuscript. The list of paper types therefore provides incomplete coverage of the volume.
support.material: ff. 1-30, ff. 176-209 Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark: Crescent ( 13 15 ) in the gutter, similar to Briquet 5190. This example is dated to 1551. It is possible that this is merely the upper part of a larger watermark, such as the one present on ff. 126-129, the remainder of which may be concealed by repairs.
ff. 31-35, ff. 88-91 Western paper, folded in quarto. The watermark is not visible; the countermark resembles those of, for example, Mošin 2119, 2125-2126, dated to 1610-1620.
ff. 36-45 Western paper, folded in quarto. The watermark is not visible the countermark contains a trefoil above the letter A and another letter which is unclear.

ff. 72-79, ff. 136-139, ff. 223-230 Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark: Anchor ( c. 65 c. 40 ) in the gutter, similar to Velkov Ancre inscrite dans un cercle 46-47. These examples are dated to 1619-1620.

ff. 124-125, ff. 130-131 Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark: Anchor ( c. 55 c. 40 ) in the gutter, similar to Mošin 1985, 2021, Velkov Ancre inscrite dans un cercle 132, 136-137. These examples are dated to 1586-1610.

ff. 126-129 Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark: Crown ( c. 50 23 ) in the gutter, similar but not identical to Heawood 1129, 1131, and with a different countermark, containing a trefoil and the letters B and G. The former example is dated to c. 1565, the latter is undated.

ff. 231-246 Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark: Anchor ( c. 65 c. 45 ) in the gutter, similar to Velkov Ancre inscrite dans un cercle 206-207, 220-223, 226-231, 233-236, 240, 242-258, 263, 267-268, 277-288, 290. These examples are dated to 1625-1649.
ff. 247-261 Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark: Anchor ( c. 60 37 ) in the gutter, similar but not identical to Mošin 2417. This example is dated to 1565-1575.

supportDesc.foliation: The manuscript is foliated with the numbers [i-iii] + 1-261 + [iv-vi], in Arabic numerals, in pencil, recto, upper right.

collation.p: The manuscript consists of 42 quires, of which one was of twelve folios, one is a quinion, one is a ternion, five are binia, two are single bifolios, five are single folios and the rest are quaternia.

list.item: Quire 18-1 ff. 1-7 The first folio has been lost or cancelled
Quire 38-1 ff. 16-22 The last folio has been lost, with loss of text
Quire 58-3 ff. 31-35 The first three folios have been lost, with loss of text
Quire 71 f. 46 This folio is bound out of position: it should follow f. 135
Quire 81 f. 47 This folio is bound out of position: it should follow f. 48
Quire 108-1 ff. 49-55 The first folio has been lost, with loss of text
Quire 224 ff. 136-139 This quire is bound out of position: it should follow f. 261
Quire 3212-3 ff. 193-201 The tenth, eleventh and twelfth folios have been lost, with loss of text
Quire 348-3 ff. 210-214 The first three folios have been lost, with loss of text

collation.signatures: There are quire signatures in Greek numerals, probably originally in black ink but faded due to water damage, on the first folio of Quires 2-4, recto, upper right (ιʹ-ιβʹ). As these begin from the number 10, the incomplete Quire 1, forming a continuous sequence with Quire 2, was presumably number 9 of this sequence, indicating the loss of eight preceding quires. These are probably original to the production of the manuscript. Crosses, probably of the same origin, have been marked in the centre of the upper margin of the first folio of each quire, recto, and the last folio of each quire, verso, on Quires 1-4.
A similar signature in a new sequence, also combined with crosses, appears on Quire 6 with the number 2 (βʹ). This suggests that the incomplete Quire 5 was number 1 in this sequence.

Another sequence of original signatures, in Greek numerals, in brown ink, appears on the first folio of each quire, recto, upper right, and the last folio of each quire, verso, lower left, beginning with the number 10, on Quires 10-12, (ιʹ-ιβʹ). These are also combined with crosses.

A cross marking the beginning of a new quire appears on the first folio of Quire 14, recto, in the centre of the upper margin. Another cross has been placed, perhaps later, in the upper right-hand corner.
A cross marking the beginning of a new quire appears on the first folio of Quire 17, recto, in the centre of the upper margin.

Another sequence of signatures in Greek numerals, in black or brown ink, appears on the first folio of each quire, recto, upper right, beginning with the number 2, on Quires 19-20 (βʹ-γʹ). This suggests that Quire 18 was number 1 in this sequence. These are also combined with crosses.

Another sequence of original signatures in Greek numerals, in black ink, appears on the first folio of each quire, recto, upper right, and the last folio of each quire, verso, upper right, beginning with the number 1, on Quires 26-34 (αʹ-ηʹ). Signatures of the same sequence, in red or black ink, on the last folio of each quire, verso, lower right or lower centre, also appear on Quires 27-30. This sequence is also combined with crosses.
collation.catchwords: Original catchwords appear on the last folio of Quires 1-2, 5, 10-11, 18-20, 26-28, 30-31 and 33-34, verso, lower right.

supportDesc.condition: There is widespread and serious pest damage through most of the manuscript, in places causing minor loss of text, which has led to extensive repairs with paper patches, with transparent patches in the written area. These repairs have caused hingeing and restrict the opening. Much of the manuscript has also suffered extensive water staining, leading in places to fading of text in the uppermost lines. On ff. 160r and 210r-261v, this is accompanied by green stains in the upper margin. Iron gall corrosion is present in places. There are areas of dirt and drops of wax.

layoutDesc.layout:
ff. 1r-30v, 108r-135r, line 11, ff. 151r-209v A single column of 18 lines. Written space
135 85
ff. 31r-44v, line 11 A single column of 15 lines. Written space 132 80
ff. 44v-48v, 68r, line 7-f. 71v, 79r-79v, f. 89v, lines 14-24, ff. 106v-107v, 135, line 12-f. 150v A single column of 18-30 lines. Written space 137-185 90-130

ff. 49r-68r, line 6, ff. 72r-72v, 92r-106r A single column of 18 lines. Written space
153 90-95

ff. 73r-78v A single column of 19 lines. Written space
132 85

f. 80r-89v A single column of 18 lines. Written space
135 90
f. 89v, line 10-f. 91v, line 13 A single column of 18 lines. Written space 135 85-95
ff. 210r-261v A single column of 20 lines. Written space 145 95

handNote.p: The main text of ff. 1r-30v, 108r-135r, line 11, ff. 151r-209v were copied by Hand A in a calligraphic Hodegon-style mixed minuscule script, slanting to the right, in black ink. There is moderate variation in letter size and frequent flourishing of tails into the margin. When appearing in the bottom line, some letters often form triple loops below, often with red infill in the loops (e.g. ff. 1r, 13r). Loops of letters and the inside of curves are also sometimes filled with red ink. Letters and abbreviations in the bottom line often have long, kinked tail in a pattern forming a space in which a red dot has been placed, sometimes overlaid with silver (e.g. f. 1r), or sometimes a more ornate decoration (e.g. ff. 16r, 190v, 192r).

Syllabic abbreviations and superscription of word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is subscript. There is decorative use of the double dot, and accentuation of all nomina sacra. Accents are sometimes joined to letters. The double grave accent is in use.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points, lower and middle commas, question mark and full stop. Punctuation is mostly marked in red.
Headings to ff. 1r-30v were copied by Hand B in a mixed minuscule script, slanting to the right, in red ink.
Breathings are round and mute iota is subscript. There is decorative use of the double dot. Breathings are sometimes joined to letters. The modern eta and sigma telikon are present.

ff. 31r-44v, line 11 were copied by Hand C in Hodegon-style mixed minuscule script, slanting to the right, in black ink. There is moderate variation in letter size and frequent flourishing of tails into the margin.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscription of word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is subscript. There is decorative use of the double dot, and accentuation of all nomina sacra. Accents are sometimes joined to letters. The double grave accent is in use. Breathings and accents are often positioned markedly to the left.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points, lower and middle commas, question mark and full stop.

f. 44v, line 13-f. 48v, f. 68r, line 7-f. 71v, f. 79r-79v, f. 91v, lines 14-24, ff. 106v-107v, f. 135r, line 12-f. 135v, f. 136r, line 9-f, 150v were copied by Hand D in mixed minuscule script, slanting to the right, in black ink. There is moderate variation in letter size.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscription of word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is subscript. There is decorative use of the double dot, and accentuation of all nomina sacra. Accents are sometimes joined to letters, breathings and abbreviations. The double grave accent is in use.
The modern eta, modern nu, sigma telikon and loop epsilon are present.
Punctuation used includes the lower, middle and upper points, lower and middle commas, question mark and full stop.
Headings are written in the same style in red ink.

ff. 49r-68r, line 6, ff. 72r-72v, 92r-106r were copied by Hand E in a Hodegon-style mixed minuscule script, slanting to the right, in brown ink. There is modest variation in letter size and some flourishing of tails into the margin. When appearing in the bottom line, some letters form multiple loops below, with red infill in the loops.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscription of word endings are rare but appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is subscript. There is decorative use of the double dot, and accentuation of all nomina sacra.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points, lower comma, question mark and full stop.
Headings are written in the same style in red ink.

ff. 73r-78v were copied by Hand F in Hodegon-style mixed minuscule script, with variable slant, in black ink. There is moderate variation in letter size, occasionally dramatic. When appearing in the bottom line, some letters form multiple loops below, with red infill. Loops of letters and the inside of curves are also sometimes filled with red ink.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscription of word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is absent or subscript. There is decorative use of the double dot, and accentuation of all nomina sacra.
Majuscule delta often carries a long, downward-slanting ascender.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points, lower and middle commas and full stop. Punctuation points are usually marked in red ink, commas in black ink.
Headings are written in the same style, in red ink.

ff. 80r-89v, line 9 were copied by Hand G in Hodegon-style mixed minuscule script, slanting to the right, in black ink. There is substantial variation in letter size and frequent flourishing of tails into the margin. When appearing in the bottom line, some letters form multiple loops below.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscription of word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is absent. Use of the double dot is functional only, and there is accentuation of all nomina sacra. Accents are sometimes joined to letters.
Majuscule alpha often carries a long ascender turning to the horizontal. Minuscule sigma commonly appears with its tail curved down to the base of the letter or below.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points, lower and middle commas and full stop.
Headings are written in the same style, in red ink.

f. 89v, line 10-f. 91v, line 13 were copied by Hand H in Hodegon-style mixed minuscule script, slanting to the right, in black ink. There is moderate variation in letter size and some flourishing of tails into the margin. Loops of letters and the inside of curves are sometimes filled with red ink.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscription of word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is subscript. There is decorative use of the double dot, and accentuation of all nomina sacra. Accents are sometimes joined to letters.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points, lower and middle commas and full stop. Punctuation is often marked in red ink.

handDesc.handNote: The heading on f. 89v was written by Hand I in mixed minuscule script, slanting to the right, in red ink. Breathings are round and mute iota is subscript. Accents are sometimes joined to breathings. When unaccentuated, iota is often topped by a single dot. Punctuation used includes the lower comma and full stop.

handNote.p: f. 136r, lines 1-8, ff. 210r-261v were copied by Hand J in mixed minuscule script, slanting slightly to the right, in black ink. There is modest variation in letter size.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscription of word endings appear rarely but throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is absent or subscript. There is decorative use of the double dot, and accentuation of all nomina sacra. Accents are sometimes joined to letters and breathings. Marginal quottion marks are used.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points, lower and middle commas, question mark and full stop.

decoDesc.decoNote: Sme texts and sections begin with minor initals in red ink.
Transitions between some texts are marked by simple vignettes in red and black ink (e.g. f. 11r).

additions.p: There are occasional marginal annotations in Greek by various hands (e.g. ff. 73r, 78r-78v, 80v-81v, 199v).

A note on f. [i] verso records the acquisition of the manuscript by Rouse: W.H. D. Rouse bought in Calymnos 1898. Another records its donation to Christ's College: Presented to the Library July 3rd 1940. The former classmark Y.14 is marked here and on ff. [ii] recto and [iii] verso, and has been cancelled in the two former locations.

binding.p: Late 19th or early 20-century full leather binding over millboards, with marbled paper pastedowns. The description Basil, Ephraim Syrus, Chrysostom (extracts) anecdotes, etc. Greek MS is tooled in blind on the spine.

history.origin: The manuscript was probably produced in the last third of the 16th century, as suggested by the dating of MS Rouse 255, since Hand A and Hand G also worked on that manuscript.
history.provenance: Bought by the classicist and teacher W.H.D. Rouse (1863-1950) Rouse, W.H.D. (William Henry Denham), 1863-1950 , Honorary Fellow of Christ's, on Kalymnos in 1898, according to his note on f. [i] verso.
history.acquisition: Presented to Christ's College by Rouse, 3 July 1940.

availability.p: Visitors to Christ's who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Christ's College Old Library.
